Date: Mon, 22 Oct 2001 14:10:07 -0400 (EDT)
Subject: If a test fails (on an error), is tearDown called anyway?
To: JUnit Mailing list <junit@yahoogroups.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE
Message-Id: <20011022181434.E96214688A@...>
From: Laurent Duperval <lduperval@...>
X-Yahoo-Profile: lduperval

Hi,

In the process of debugging my transaction problem reported last Frida=
y, I
decided to recode the offending tests so they are no longer transactio=
nal.
I've found that if the test is run alone, it passes, but if it is run =
within
a slew of test suites (AllTests), it fails. If we take the test suit=
e for
the offending class and put it first in AllTests, it passes.

In our =
transactional tests, the tearDown method ends the transaction. If a
test fa=
ils because of an error, is tearDown called nevertheless? Has anyone
seen w=
eird side effects where a test run standAlone passes but fails when
run wit=
h others?

No, at this point, I can't say that it's due to data cleanup. Al=
l our tests
recreate data when they are run. Furthermore, most of our data =
uses database
sequence numbers as the primary key so every test run uses a =
new set of
data. Even if previous data was still in the DB, it can't be map=
ped to the
new data.

L

-- 
Laurent Duperval <mailto:lduperval@microcelli5=
.com>

D'obscures manoeuvres ont eu lieu dans l'ombre et je ferai toute la =
lumi=E8re
sur ces t=E9n=E9breux agissements! C'est du march=E9 noir!
      =
                                       -Achille Talon
